awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project ultimately will allow researchers to better understand the brain and improve the productivity of neurological studies.  The societal impact of this invention will help researchers, scientists, and physicians alike make precise neurochemical measurements in the brain to better understand complex behaviors, diseases, and drug states. Carbon multielectrode arrays technology  will enable measurements in the brain to better understand brain heterogeneity and neurological diseases that burden our society such as addiction/drug abuse, epilepsy, depression and anxiety.  These multielectrode arrays will perform complex measurements of neurotransmitters in multiple brain regions simultaneously. The commercial potential for this novel technology is substantial in that, currently, there is no existing device that can simultaneously measure neurotransmission in multiple brain regions.  These benefits should  be of value to investigators, clinicians, and researchers in government, academic, and research institutions as well as industry.

This I-Corps project will use carbon coated metal wires and carbon fibers as electrode materials to design, develop, and engineer multielectrode arrays. These multielectrode arrays will be used as electrode materials to detect neurotransmitters such as dopamine, serotonin, norepinephrine, and others in multiple brain regions simultaneously. This technology is cutting edge as no other neurological device has been developed with carbon fiber multielectrode arrays to be utilized as biosensors. This research will utilize fast scan cyclic voltammetry (FSCV) to detect neurotransmitters in preclinical models.  A changing voltage will be applied to the electrode material to measure neurochemical changes in vivo in animal models. The technical results on which the project is based arise from laboratory experiments that have further developed these multielectrode arrays. The carbon fiber multielectrode arrays have been immersed in prepared neurotransmitter stock solutions in the laboratory and have successfully measured dopamine and other neurotransmitters using FSCV and data analysis software.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The project “I-Corps: Multielectrode Array Biosensor” detailed the development of a multielectrode array biosensor that will be able to measure neurochemical changes in multiple brain regions simultaneously. Our work will give researchers, scientists, and physicians alike the tools to measure neurochemicals in multiple brain regions simultaneously to help further diagnose and treat several neurological conditions. For example, dopamine is found in high concentrations in the nucleus accumbens and regulates reward, which is important for understanding the function of drugs of abuse. Conversely, the death of dopaminergic neurons and the depletion of dopamine could cause movement disorders such as Parkinson’s Disease. On the other hand, measuring serotonin dynamics in the hippocampus could help treat and diagnose depression and measure the efficacy of several anti-depressants.  Our potential customers are academic, pharmaceutical, and government researchers. We also hope to tap the physician-scientist market as well.

                Through the NSF I-Corps program, our team traveled to several conference and expositions to help meet potential customers who would be interested in these multielectrode array biosensor devices. We received crucial information and feedback on the engineering of these devices such as materials (carbon, metal, etc.), length of the shaft, insulation, spacing, number of arrays, and other customizable parameters. We realized that customizing the design and development of these multielectrode array biosensor probes to the specific needs of our potential customers will produce a highly sought and greatly impactful product. Scientists will now be able to monitor neurotransmission in multiple brain regions simultaneously. These arrays are small, minimally invasive, highly biocompatible, and have high spatial and temporal resolution to measure fast subsecond changes of neurochemicals in multiple regions simultaneously. Through the coupling with fast-scan cyclic voltammetry (FSCV), the technique also has high sensitivity and selectivity to measure these neurochemical activity in real-time. This work will have vast implications in the fields of bioanalytical chemistry and neuroscience to help understand the effects of complex behaviors, neurological disorders, and drug application on real-time changes of fast neurotransmitters. Researchers and physicians scientists alike will seek out the devices to study the effects of psychostimulants, Parkinson’s Disease, and behavioral tasks amongst several other applications.

                This work has already produced several publications and conference presentations and was followed up with a funded small business technology transfer grant award from the National Institutes of Health. We hope to develop an in-demand biosensor that will be highly sought after and that will potentially make a great impact in the field of neurochemical research.

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2023
Modified by: Alexander G Zestos
